Award.AwardTitle: OP: Collaborative Research: Active Speckle Control and Fast Speckle Statistics to Drastically Improve the Contrast Ratio of Exoplanet Direct Imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
Astronomers would like to image habitable planets around other stars. Turbulence in Earth's atmosphere is the main obstacle to achieving this goal. Such turbulence blurs and confuses light from bright stars with their nearby, dim planets. Adaptive optics can partially correct for turbulence. However, even adaptive optics pushed to its limits (Extreme Adaptive Optics, ExAO) is still insufficient to deliver the required high-contrast images. Mazin and collaborators will develop an innovative control algorithm that makes use of new, highly responsive detectors. This approach will enable ExAO images to separate exoplanets from their parent stars. The resulting algorithm will be tested and used at several observatories. This technology may enable breakthrough advances in ground-based astronomy and allow the discovery of habitable worlds outside our solar system.

This proposal is a continuation of Microwave Kinetic Inductance Detector (MKID) research and development that was supported by previous NSF awards (1308556 and1654105). These previous awards supported the instrument development and deployment at Palomar Observatory. This award will develop algorithms and methodology to use the instrument to increase contrast in Extreme Adaptive Optics (ExAO) images of exoplanets. Increasing contrast is the main technical challenge for imaging exoplanets with ExAO. The greatest obstacle is short timescale atmospheric speckles that are uncorrected by the AO system. This proposal will use the fast time response of the MKID detectors to remove speckles from images ex post facto using the photon arrival time statistics. Direct detection and study of Earth-like exoplanets would realize a major goal of astronomy in the coming decade.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Direct Imaging is one of the most technically challenging techniques to study exoplanets, but holds immense promise for not just detecting but characterizing planets around the nearest stars.  Ambitious instruments at the world's largest telescopes have been built to carry out this science: the Gemini Planet Imager (GPI), SPHERE at VLT, SCExAO at Subaru, MagAO-X at Magellan South, the Stellar Double Coronagraph (SDC) + DARKNESS at Palomar, and the Keck Planet Imager and Characterizer (KPIC) at W.M. Keck Observatory.  All of these instruments are currently limited to planet-star detection contrast ratios of 1e-6 by a background of speckles from uncontrolled scattered and diffracted light. The most problematic speckles are mostly short (< sec) timescale atmospheric speckles due to imperfections in the adaptive optics (AO) systems.  This is the “speckle barrier” that has limited the yield of current instruments to a mere handful of young planets in wide orbits.

In order to make real progress, we must break through the speckle barrier. Much like the sound barrier, the speckle barrier is not a true limit but an obstacle for our current technology.  We believe the key advance to shattering the speckle barrier are fast, read-noise free IR imaging arrays.

Our proposed work is extremely timely, as fast-frame-rate photon-counting detector arrays are now available.  When placed at the science focal plane, a fast photon-counting detector array will for the first time allow us to sense (and correct for) atmospheric speckles in real time, as well as perform an ex post facto removal of speckles using photon arrival time statistics.

Among this class of detectors are Microwave Kinetic Inductance Detectors (MKIDs).  Our team has developed two instruments based on this technology. Our instruments on Palomar and Subaru are online (or coming online) and constitute the premier facilities for our proposed work.  The NSF has funded DARKNESS, a fast photon counting, energy resolving integral field spectrograph (IFS) based on MKIDs for use at the Palomar 200'' telescope's Stellar Double Coronagraph (SDC). The Japanese government has funded MEC, a similar instrument for the Subaru Telescope's SCExAO system.  DARKNESS was commissioned in summer 2016, and MEC was commissioned in spring 2018.

Our calculations show that the use of photon counting detectors can push the contrast ratio from the current 1e-6 down by up to two orders of magnitude. Proving this contrast ratio is possible from the ground will be vital for direct imaging instruments designed for 30-m class telescopes.  A 30-m telescope with a ~1e-8 contrast ratio will be able to image Earth-mass planets in the habitable zones of nearby M dwarfs, and spectroscopy may be able to detect the signatures of life in their atmospheres.

For this collaborative program, Caltech has been focussing on the development of various wavefront sensing and control algorithms: including the Speckle Nulling Algorithm with a Kalman Filter Estimator, as well as a new Electric Field Conjugation algorithm with System Identification and Variational Learning using TensorFlow.

At the beginning of this program in 2017-2018, Caltech was involved in the DARKNESS run at Palomar observatory in collaboration with the UCSB team. This run led to the successful implementation of fast atmospheric speckle control (Milestone 1) using a code based on a Caltech-developed speckle nulling pipeline, which formed the basis for the speckle nulling algorithm now being used on MEC at Subaru Observatory. The fast algorithm was demonstrated with the white light source, but poor weather prevented an on-sky demonstration. A Caltech graduate student participated in the run preparation and implemented the Kalman filter algorithm to the new fast speckle nulling pipeline.

The algorithms were developed and tested in the ET Lab by a team of Caltech postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students. Some of the results were presented at 2018 and 2019 SPIE conferences, and published in a peer-review journal JATIS (Llop Sayson et al. 2019, JATIS 5, 1-11). Another paper, which best embodies the collaborative aspect of this work has been submitted to JATIS (Data-driven subspace predictive control of adaptive optics for high-contrast imaging.", Sebastiaan Haffert, Jared Males, Laird Close, Kyle Van Gorkom, Joseph Long, Alexander Hedglen, Olivier Guyon, Lauren Schatz, Maggie Kautz, Jennifer Lumbres, Alexander Rodack, Justin Knight, He Sun, and Kevin Fogarty).

In terms of broader impacts, this program has been instrumental in training a new cohort of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral fellows in advanced wavefront control techniques. It reinforced collaborative networks between participants at Caltech, the University of Arizona, the University of California and the observatories (W.M. Keck Observatory, Palomar Observatory, Subaru, and Magellan). This effort paved the way to novel instrumentation and techniques on the Giant Magellan Telescope and the Thirty Meter Telescope, inching our community closer to achieving the promise of future extremely large 30-m telescopes for exoplanet imaging and spectroscopy.
